#Text=New Zealand 's anti-spam legislation kicks in –
#Text=exclusive report
#Text=Wednesday , September 5 , 2007
#Text=Freelance journalist , Gabriel Pollard , spoke to Joe Stewart and David Farrar about the new anti- spam legislation in New Zealand that comes into effect today .

#Text=Joe Stewart is the Unit Manager of the Department of Internal Affairs new Anti-Spam Compliance Unit , and David Farrar is Chair of InternetNZ ’s Public Policy Committee , who also had significant input into the final bill .
#Text=Keith Norris , CEO of the New Zealand Marketing Association , did n't respond to multiple requests for an interview .

#Text=The anti-spam legislation , or the Unsolicited Electronic Messages Act 2007 , promotes spam education and awareness and will enable international agencies to work together to share information and will enable cross-border pursuit of serious law breakers .
#Text=And it does n't just cover e-mail spam , but all electronic messaging such as SMS/text messaging , etc.
#Text=However , New Zealand is n't the most up-to-date country with implementing similar legislation , Farrar says , “ We are in fact almost the last country in the OECD to have such legislation . ”
#Text=He urges Eastern Europe and China to take part in the fight against spam .
#Text=Stewart said that the new law would only help combat a small amount of spam , as 99%-99.9 % of all spam received originates from overseas .
#Text=He says the legislation alone will not solve the problem .

#Text=As well as it helping to fight New Zealand-sourced spam and preventing New Zealand from “ becoming a haven for spammers ” , it will promote good practices within the e-marketing community , Stewart said .
#Text=The new Act will affect legitimate marketers in New Zealand by making sure they have expressed or inferred consent to continue sending marketing messages to people on their database .
#Text=Inferred consent is where the marketers have the e-mail address and send messages to those on their database , but did n't get expressed consent to send messages .
#Text=Stewart does issue a warning against using inferred consent saying , “ They may have been sending these people messages for years , but this does not establish consent . ”
#Text=A surge in emails has also been felt with companies/marketers making sure they have consent to continue the e-mails and asking those to confirm they wish to continue their subscription .
#Text=“
#Text=However , many marketers are already fulfilling these requirements because they are standard good e-marketing practice , ” Stewart said .

#Text=Due to legislative requirements , as well as having consent , businesses will have to provide details about the company sending the item , and provide a free way to unsubscribe from future mailings .
#Text=Those found breaking these requirements deliberately could find themselves facing a personal fine of up to NZ$ 200,000 .
#Text=Organisations could face a fine of up to $ 500,000 .
#Text=Farrar said , “ Experience from Australia shows most cases are dealt with by way of education . ”
#Text=Farrar also gives a final piece of advice to those annoyed with spam levels , “ Never ever respond to a spam e-mail , and only give your real address out to people you trust . ”
